prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe CH3CN, CH3CCH, CH3OH towards a sample of high mass protostars.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For constraining the excitation and column density of the molecules, the line does not need to be highly spectrally resolved as integrated intensity is the key observational quantity.

At the maximum distance of these sources (5kpc), a beam of 800 mas will sample a region 2500 AU in radius which is well matched to the size of the inner circumstellar regions of the sources where the effects of the stellar heating will be most apparent as well as allowing the sepatation of different parts of the sources, if for example, outflows are affecting the circumstellar material. The maximum angular scale will be sufficient to probe the outer regions where protostar heating is significant, potentially allowing imaging of the excitation as a function of distance from the central source.

The rms noise level is set by the requirement to adequately detect the high k components of CH3CN to well constrain the gas temperature. For source with low abundances of organic species models indicate that these k components will have peak fluxes of about 50mJy. Previous observations show that the sources are expected to have line widths of about 3 km/s.

The data rate of 12.21 MB/s is only slightly above the policy value. This is a result of the need to cover the full range of molecular species to adequately characterise the chemistry of these sources, with an adequate velocity resolution. Moving to a narrower bandwidth would not be possible without excluding some important species.
For constraining the excitation and column density of the molecules, the line does not need to be highly spectrally resolved as integrated intensity is the key observational quantity.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent surveys of the Galactic plane have identified large populations of candidate young massive protostars. However we have a very poor understanding of the actual evolutionary status of these sources. The SED based classification schemes used for nearby low mass objects are, alone, inadequate at the large distances of these high mass objects which are embedded in inhomogeneous environments. Here we propose the first comprehensive, systematic, high angular resolution survey of the chemical (and physical) properties of a well selected sample of 39 young high mass embedded sources. This survey will use a single frequency setting to study a range of organic molecular species which trace the evolution of the circumstellar material as a protostar initially heats its environment. The column density and excitation temperature of these species, together with the dust continuum emission, will be used to study how the properties of the circumstellar molecular gas change with source luminosity, spectral energy distribution and other properties with the goal of identifying evolutionary trends.
